children.name: highlight
children.definition: to make a problem or subject easy to notice so that people pay attention to it :làm nổi bật,nêu bật
examples: Your résumé should highlight your skills and achievements.
This report highlights some of the problems faced by old people in winter.
The slump in the car industry was highlighted by Ford’s offer of a $600 rebate on new cars.
The report highlighted the need for prison reform.
The Association’s first project was to publish a 35-cent brochure highlighting nine historic sites.

children.name: underline
children.definition: /underscore if sth that happens underlines or underscores a fact, especially one that is already known, it helps to emphasize that it is true:bộc lộ
examples: Yesterday’s shelling of a Red Cross hospital underlines the difficulties faced by rescue teams.
The recent rioting in South Africa has underlined the government’s lack of control.
The dire state of child health in the country was underscored in a report by UNICEF.

children.name: drive the point home
children.definition: / drive home the point to emphasize a fact or idea by giving additional, often surprising or shocking, information about it:nhấn mạnh
examples: After the talk, the students were shown a video about heroin addiction to drive the point home.

children.name: drive the point home/drive home the point that
examples: The reconstruction of the accident certainly drove home the point that drink-driving can kill.

children.name: play up
children.definition: sth/make great play ofUK  to emphasize a fact or idea, by giving it more attention than anything else, especially if you are trying to make it seem more important than it really is:làm nổi bật
examples: At the interview, remember to play up your experience of teaching in Japan.
On TV last night the Democratic candidate was clearly playing up his caring image.
The story has been played up by the media.
The Labour party had a great time playing up the Conservatives’ problems.

children.name: make great play of (doing) sth
examples: The Prime Minister made great play of environmental issues, considering how little the government has done.

children.name: accentuate
children.definition: to emphasize sth, especially the differences between two things or situations:làm nổi bật
examples: In Britain, the choice between state and private schools accentuates the differences between rich and poor.
The director uses music to accentuate the rising dramatic tension.
The recent economic crisis has accentuated the gap between the rich and the poor.

children.name: point up
children.definition: to make sth, especially the true facts of a situation, clearer and more noticeable:nhấn mạnh
examples: Recent protests in the north of the country point up the dilemma the opposition forces are in.
Low literacy rates among the women in this area point up the need for much greater investment in girls’ education.
It was a badly researched documentary that glossed over important questions while pointing up trivial ones.

children.name: stress
children.definition: to emphasize a statement, fact, or idea

children.name: stress the importance of something
examples: He has always stressed the importance of a stable family.

children.name: stress the need for something
examples: She stressed the need for more effective policing.

children.name: stress a point
examples: This point needs to be stressed.

children.name: stress a fact
examples: Medicines usually stress the fact that you must not exceed the stated dose.

children.name: stress the role of somebody/something
examples: In her speech, she stressed the role of parents in preventing youth crime.

children.name: stress your commitment to
children.definition: doing
examples: somethingThe President stressed his commitment to tackling world poverty.

children.name: stress that
examples: The report stressed that student math skills need to improve.
Mann stressed the need to educate people about the risks of AIDS.

children.name: emphasize
children.definition: / emphasiseUK to say strongly or show clearly that a fact, idea etc is especially important : nhấn mạnh
examples: Our company emphasizes the need for good communication between staff.
The reportemphasizestheimportanceof improving safety standards.
Logan made a speechemphasizingtheneedfor more volunteers.

children.name: emphasize that/how
examples: The Prime Minister emphasized that there are no plans to raise taxes.
The County Sheriff emphasized that there was no evidence to show that the driver had been drinking.
I'd just like to emphasizehowimportant it is for people to learn foreign languages.

children.name: I can’t emphasize enoughspoken this needs to be emphasized a lot
examples: I can’t emphasize enough how grateful we are for your donations.

children.name: to make a word or phrase noticable
underline
children.definition: (alsounderscore) to draw a line under a word, especially in order to show its importance: gạch chân

children.name: underline sth in
examples: All the technical words have been underlined in red.

children.name: emphasize
children.definition: (alsoemphasiseUK)  to say a word or phrase louder or higher than others to give it more importanceSYN stress: nhấn mạnh
examples: She said smoking was not permitted anywhere in the school - emphasizing the word ‘anywhere’.
You can use italics or capitals to emphasize a word in a piece of writing.

children.name: stress
children.definition: B2 to pronounce a word or syllable with greater force than other words in the same sentence or other syllables in the same word, or to play a musicalnote with greater force than others in a group : sự nhấn âm
examples: In the word 'engine', you should stress the first syllable.

children.name: highlight
children.definition: to mark written words with a special coloured pen, or in a different colour on a computer :
examples: Use the cursor to highlight the name of the document you want to print.

children.name: highlight sth in
examples: The spelling mistakes in the text had been highlightedingreen.

children.name: overemphasize
children.definition: / overemphasiseUK to give something more importance than it deserves or than is suitable :
examples: I think the book overemphasizes the importance of religion in the history of the US.
In the past the exam had been overemphasized.
The importance of adequate preparationcannot be overemphasized(= used to say that something is very important ).

children.name: labour the point
children.definition: British /belabor the pointAmerican  to emphasize an idea or a fact too strongly, especially by repeating it often so that people get bored:nói đi nói lại
examples: I understand what you’re saying -- there’s no need to labour the point.
I don’t want to keep belaboring the point, but the Barnes Foundation is an educational institution, not a museum.

children.name: accent
children.definition: with the  on if sth is done with the accent on a particular quality or feature, that quality or feature is emphasized - used especially in written descriptions of products and services: chú trọng vào
examples: Toptours Travel is now offering numerous special vacation packages with the accent on choice.
a new range of children’s toys with the accent on creativity
the accent is on sth
This season the accent is definitely on long, flowing, romantic clothes.

children.name: stress
children.definition: the special attention or importance given to a particular idea, fact, or activitySYN emphasis:chú trọng, tập trung

children.name: put/lay stress on sth
examples: Pugh laid particular stress on the need for discipline.
During his speech, helaidparticular stress on the freedom of the press.

children.name: emphasis
children.definition: special attention that is given to a particular activity, subject etc, because it is believed to be more important than other things: chú trọng, tập trung, nhấn mạnh
examples: emphasis on
In Japan there is a lot of emphasis on politeness.
with the emphasis on
an exciting new French course for beginners, with the emphasis on fun

children.name: put emphasis on something
examples: We need to put greater emphasis on planning.|The airline is accused of placing more emphasis on profit than on safety.

children.name: place/lay emphasis on somethingformal
examples: The coach has placed the emphasis firmly on youth by including three teenagers in the team.

children.name: give emphasis to something
examples: Since league tables were introduced, schools have given even greater emphasis to exam results.

children.name: shift the emphasis
children.definition: change the emphasis to something else
examples: With drug addicts, we need to shift the emphasis from punishment to treatment.

children.name: add emphasis
children.definition: make an opinion or fact seem more important
examples: Put bullet points before each statement to add emphasis.

children.name: the emphasis shifts/moves
children.definition: changes
examples: The emphasis is now shifting away from oil towards renewable sources of energy.

children.name: great emphasis
examples: The company places great emphasis on customer care.

children.name: a strong/heavy emphasis
examples: There is a strong emphasis on research in the university.

children.name: the main emphasis
examples: The main emphasis must be on quality, not quantity.

children.name: particular/special emphasis
examples: The new legislation places particular emphasis on energy conservation.

children.name: increased/increasing emphasis
examples: Recently, there has been an increasing emphasis on creating more jobs.

children.name: considerable emphasis
examples: Most religions put considerable emphasis on the importance of marriage.

children.name: a change of emphasis
children.definition: alsoa shift in emphasis
examples: There has been a change of emphasis in the government’s foreign policy.

children.name: point
children.definition: /pɔɪnt/  something you say, that people had not thought about or discussed until you mentioned it:
examples: nhắc đến, ý kiến , luận điểm
point about: nhắc đến về
▪ Michael’s point about training is an interesting one.
good point: ý kiến hay
▪ That’s a good point, and we should take it into consideration.
make a point : nêu ý kiến
say something in a discussion, which people had not thought of before
▪ In his speech, Marks made the point that far more people died from smoking tobacco than from taking drugs.

children.name: exactly
children.definition: adverb

children.name: used to emphasize what you are saying
examples: _Do exactly what I tell you and no-one will get hurt!
_Exactly how do you propose to achieve this?
_What exactly do you mean?

children.name: point out
children.definition: to tell sb sth that they had not noticed or had not thought about, amistake, sth they haveforgottenetc:chỉ ra

children.name: as sb points out
examples: As Palermo pointed out, Peruvian university students tend to be highly political.
As Sharon pointed out, the story was rather hard to believe.

children.name: point out (that)
examples: It’s worth pointing out that very few people ever die of this disease.
I pointed out that changing the date would mean rescheduling the press conference.

children.name: point sth out/ point out sth
examples: He pointed out the dangers of setting off without the right equipment.
He never used to notice when people took advantage of him, so I started pointing it out.

children.name: point it out
examples: I didn’t realise I’d made a mistake. Thank you for pointing it out.

children.name: point sth out to sb
examples: Thank you for pointing this out to me.
